DataElement.preferredName: Cancer Identification Histology and Behavior ICD-O-3 Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The codes that describe a group of subfields describing the type and behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3 codes.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Cancer Identification Histology and Behavior ICD-O-3 Code
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A group of subfields describing the type and behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3 codes.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Identified; having the identity known or established.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The procedure of having an identity established.

Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:human or animal activity studied in terms of motivation, direction, result, emotion, perception, or etiology.:Indicates the matching ICD-O-3 code for the NCI Thesaurus concept.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli.
Indicates the matching ICD-O-3 code for the NCI Thesaurus concept.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Histology and Behavior International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, Third Edition (ICD-O-3) Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli._A system of numbered categories for representation of data. [Explanatory Comment: See ICD-O-3 Morphology Section and Behavior Section for codes.]_The third edition of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, published in 2000, used principally in tumor and cancer registries for coding the site (topography) and the histology (morphology) of neoplasms.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, Third Edition Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The third edition of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, published in 2000, used principally in tumor and cancer registries for coding the site (topography) and the histology (morphology) of neoplasms.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, Third Edition
Concepts.definition: The third edition of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, published in 2000, used principally in tumor and cancer registries for coding the site (topography) and the histology (morphology) of neoplasms.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
